â
''20Ten'' received mixed reviews from most music critics. Columnist [[Tony Parsons (British journalist)|Tony Parsons]] reviewed the album for the ''Daily Mirror'', the newspaper marketing the album.<ref>{{Cite news |first=Paul |last=Morley |title=Paul Morley on music: Prince |date=July 11, 2010 |newspaper=[[The Observer]] |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/music/2010/jul/11/paul-morley-on-music-prince |accessdate=July 11, 2010 | location=London}}</ref> He wrote that it was "as good as [Prince's] all-time classics like ''[[Purple Rain (album)|Purple Rain]]'' and ''[[1999 (album)|1999]]'' " and that it's "his best record since ''[[Sign o' the Times (album)|Sign o' the Times]]'' 23 years ago."<ref name="Parsons">{{Cite news |first=Tony |last=Parsons |authorlink=Tony Parsons (British journalist) |title=Prince - 20TEN the first review: This is his best album for 23 years says Tony Parsons |date=July 7, 2010 |newspaper=Daily Mirror |url=http://www.mirror.co.uk/celebs/news/2010/07/07/prince-20ten-the-first-review-this-is-his-best-album-for-23-years-says-tony-parsons-115875-22386952/ |accessdate=July 8, 2010 }}</ref> Joachim Hentschel, writing for the German edition of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', viewed the album as Prince's best effort since 1992's [[File:Prince logo.svg|12px]] (the ''[[Love Symbol Album]]'').<ref name="Hentschel">{{cite web|url=http://www.rollingstone.de/news/article.php?article_file=1278456060.txt |title= Prince: Was erwartet uns auf "20Ten"? |work=Rolling Stone |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5rMqhc9MV |archivedate=2010-07-20}}</ref> Jason Draper of ''[[NME]]'' gave ''20Ten'' a 4/10 rating, stating that while it "has its moments", the album was "no way" his best in 23 years, but likely his best in four years.<ref name="Draper">{{Cite web |first=Jason |last=Draper |title=Album Review: Prince, '20Ten' (NPG) |date=July 12, 2010 |publisher=[[NME]] |url=http://www.nme.com/reviews/prince/11437 |accessdate=July 12, 2010 }}</ref> [[MusicOMH]] writer Luke Winkie gave it 2 out of 5 stars and described it as "one of the slightest albums the man has ever recorded; fluffy, anti-climatic, and utterly boring".<ref name="Winkie">{{Cite web |first=Winkie |last=Luke |title=Prince - 20Ten |date=July 12, 2010 |publisher=[[MusicOMH]] |url=http://www.musicomh.com/albums/prince-5_0710.htm |accessdate=July 20, 2010 }}</ref> [[Stephen Thomas Erlewine]] of [[Allmusic]] gave the album 2Â½ out of 5 stars and wrote that its songs feature "enough of a shape to be attractive from a distance, not enough to withstand closer scrutiny... hooks donât sink in, funk jams are stuck in low gear, sensuality only simmers, the rhythms are somewhat stiff, and Princeâs deliberate mining of the past only highlights how heâs stripped the freakiness out of his entire persona".<ref name="Erlewine">{{Cite web |first=Stephen Thomas |last=Erlewine |title=20TEN > Review |date=July 12, 2010 |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |url=http://www.allmusic.com/cg/amg.dll?p=amg&sql=10:wxfoxzqrldhe~T1 |accessdate=July 20, 2010 }}</ref>
+
''20Ten'' received mixed reviews from most music critics. Columnist [[Tony Parsons (British journalist)|Tony Parsons]] reviewed the album for the ''Daily Mirror'', the newspaper marketing the album.<ref>{{Cite news |first=Paul |last=Morley |title=Paul Morley on music: Prince |date=July 11, 2010 |newspaper=[[The Observer]] |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/music/2010/jul/11/paul-morley-on-music-prince |accessdate=July 11, 2010 | location=London}}</ref> He wrote that it was "as good as [Prince's] all-time classics like ''[[Purple Rain (album)|Purple Rain]]'' and ''[[1999 (album)|1999]]'' " and that it's "his best record since ''[[Sign o' the Times (album)|Sign o' the Times]]'' 23 years ago."<ref name="Parsons">{{Cite news |first=Tony |last=Parsons |authorlink=Tony Parsons (British journalist) |title=Prince - 20TEN the first review: This is his best album for 23 years says Tony Parsons |date=July 7, 2010 |newspaper=Daily Mirror |url=http://www.mirror.co.uk/celebs/news/2010/07/07/prince-20ten-the-first-review-this-is-his-best-album-for-23-years-says-tony-parsons-115875-22386952/ |accessdate=July 8, 2010 }}</ref> Joachim Hentschel, writing for the German edition of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', viewed the album as Prince's best effort since 1992's the ''[[Love Symbol Album]]''.<ref name="Hentschel">{{cite web|url=http://www.rollingstone.de/news/article.php?article_file=1278456060.txt |title= Prince: Was erwartet uns auf "20Ten"? |work=Rolling Stone |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5rMqhc9MV |archivedate=2010-07-20}}</ref> Jason Draper of ''[[NME]]'' gave ''20Ten'' a 4/10 rating, stating that while it "has its moments", the album was "no way" his best in 23 years, but likely his best in four years.<ref name="Draper">{{Cite web |first=Jason |last=Draper |title=Album Review: Prince, '20Ten' (NPG) |date=July 12, 2010 |publisher=[[NME]] |url=http://www.nme.com/reviews/prince/11437 |accessdate=July 12, 2010 }}</ref> [[MusicOMH]] writer Luke Winkie gave it 2 out of 5 stars and described it as "one of the slightest albums the man has ever recorded; fluffy, anti-climatic, and utterly boring".<ref name="Winkie">{{Cite web |first=Winkie |last=Luke |title=Prince - 20Ten |date=July 12, 2010 |publisher=[[MusicOMH]] |url=http://www.musicomh.com/albums/prince-5_0710.htm |accessdate=July 20, 2010 }}</ref> [[Stephen Thomas Erlewine]] of [[Allmusic]] gave the album 2Â½ out of 5 stars and wrote that its songs feature "enough of a shape to be attractive from a distance, not enough to withstand closer scrutiny... hooks donât sink in, funk jams are stuck in low gear, sensuality only simmers, the rhythms are somewhat stiff, and Princeâs deliberate mining of the past only highlights how heâs stripped the freakiness out of his entire persona".<ref name="Erlewine">{{Cite web |first=Stephen Thomas |last=Erlewine |title=20TEN > Review |date=July 12, 2010 |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |url=http://www.allmusic.com/cg/amg.dll?p=amg&sql=10:wxfoxzqrldhe~T1 |accessdate=July 20, 2010 }}</ref>
